abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, though only modest institutional
            development impacts were achieved. Lessons convey the
            following. The need for clear objectives at appraisal, is
            once again being reinforced, particularly important if, as
            in this case, the weight of preparation predominantly fell
            on Bank staff, and consultants, rather than on the
            Government itself. Consequently, during implementation, it
            appeared the Government was not prepared to use project
            funds for expenditures such as emergency, and technical
            assistance, although funding provision was included. Thus,
            the Bank should support the Government in seeking a blend of
            credit, and grant funding through co-financing for
            operations requiring substantial assistance as specified
            above, in partnership with nongovernmental organizations.
            While the project was designed as a three year pilot
            operation, it turned into a seven year rural development
            operation, and although there is recognition for its
            management flexibility, it is suggested pilot activities
            should be limited in size, with provision for effective
            monitoring, and evaluation systems, backed by strong Bank
            supervision. Nonetheless, following restructuring, the
            project focused on micro-projects, primarily on the
            rehabilitation, and development of social, and rural
            infrastructure, proving that simple, targeted activities
            greatly contribute to the success of such operations. As for
            land use mapping, project design should ensure that such an
            expensive tool, be part of a comprehensive strategy for land
            policy development.

abstracts.cdata!:
This report describes the Rural
            Rehabilitation Project (RRP) a three-year pilot activity to
            be carried out in support of the Mozambique
            Government's National Reconstruction Program (NRP). The
            objective of the project is to undertake pilot activities to
            support decentralized rural economic recovery, while
            simultaneously creating the capacity and procedures
            necessary to respond to the challenges of post-war national
            reconstruction. The RRP has been designed to be flexible so
            it can respond to the changes likely to occur during the
            life of the project. The design of the management and
            implementation of the project benefited from the experiences
            of past projects in Mozambique. The project has four
            components. The Support for Decentralization Component
            includes a pilot activity to test procedures for
            identifying, funding, and implementing community-based
            investment subprojects.  The Lands Component will improve
            land use information and will support the development of
            policies to demarcate smallholder lands. The Distribution of
            Agpacks Component will provide seeds and hand tools to
            smallholders returning to their traditional lands after the
            war. The Rural Water Supply Component will increase the
            coverage of the rural water supply, improve the organization
            and management of provincial water supply institutions, and
            stimulate community participation in the operation and
            maintenance of the systems.

This report describes the Rural
            Rehabilitation Project (RRP) a three-year pilot activity to
            be carried out in support of the Mozambique
            Government's National Reconstruction Program (NRP). The
            objective of the project is to undertake pilot activities to
            support decentralized rural economic recovery, while
            simultaneously creating the capacity and procedures
            necessary to respond to the challenges of post-war national
            reconstruction. The RRP has been designed to be flexible so
            it can respond to the changes likely to occur during the
            life of the project. The design of the management and
            implementation of the project benefited from the experiences
            of past projects in Mozambique. The project has four
            components. The Support for Decentralization Component
            includes a pilot activity to test procedures for
            identifying, funding, and implementing community-based
            investment subprojects.  The Lands Component will improve
            land use information and will support the development of
            policies to demarcate smallholder lands. The Distribution of
            Agpacks Component will provide seeds and hand tools to
            smallholders returning to their traditional lands after the
            war. The Rural Water Supply Component will increase the
            coverage of the rural water supply, improve the organization
            and management of provincial water supply institutions, and
            stimulate community participation in the operation and
            maintenance of the systems.
